   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   .
   #Leukocytosis: Etiology unclear, WBC ct has ranged from 13-30 during
   recent admission, blood Cx neg to date. C Diff negative, RIJ line was +
   beta strep presumably treated with vancomycin.  Urine Cx + 100,000
   yeast, currently treated with Fluconazole.  Pt is still receiving vanc
   for ?line infection.  Both RIJ & R sub clavian appear erythematous,
   will need to be removed and sent for culture.  Pt has been afebrile,
   CXR without focal infiltrate and steroids stopped on day 2 of
   admission. RUQ ultrasound shows persistent GB wall thickening but no
   other signs of cholecystitis, isolated elevation in Alk phos with
   normal Tbili is less suggestive suggestive of acalculous
   cholecystitis.  UA + WBCs, pending Cx.  D/C's diflucan last night.
   - f/u Blood/Urine Cx & sputum
   - f/[**Location 39**] read of CXR
   - d/c RIJ & dialysis line , send tips for Cx
   - change out foley
   - f/u Urine Cx, hold on empiric Abx
   - continue Vancomycin day [**8-1**] for ?line infection
   - f/u vanc trough given rapid changing renal function
   # Elevated Alk Phos: Pt was transferred due to concern of elev Alk Phos
   and GGT. Etiology still unclear, obstructive cholestasis seems unlikely
   given the repeatedly normal Tbili. Transaminases normal, hepatitis
   serologies negative. Repeated RUQ u/s show thickened GB wall with no
   stones and normal CBD, ascites but no pericholecystic fluid to suggest
   acute cholecystitis. It is unclear if this could be acalculous
   cholecystitis, would suspect that Tbili would also be elevated and pt
   would be less stable. CHF/volume overload can cause isolated Alk phos
   elevation. Fluconazole could also cause cholestatic picture.  Given h/o
   crohns, could have newly developped PSC though more commonly assoc with
   UC.   Alk Phos appears to be trending down from >900 at OSH to 750 here
   to ??? today
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - f/u BNP to evaluate for volume overload
   - NPO
   -imaging unlikely to change management
   - if not improving tomorrow would consider liver consult in am & work
   up for PSC including smooth muscle Ab, p-ANCA
   .
   # Resp Failure: Pt was intubated for airway control and has had
   prolonged intubation for unclear reasons.  Volume overload and MS
   likely contributing factors.  Per notes, attempted extubation on [**7-17**]
   but required re-intubation due to persistent hypoxia on BiPAP.
   Portable shows bilateral effusions and initial gas 7.4/48/66.  There is
   likely some component of chronic CO2 retention though no wheezing
   appreciated on exam.  Pt putting out >50cc of [**Month/Year (2) **]/hr, likely having
   post ATN natriuresis.  Chest tube still having some output
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - daily wake ups
   - wean propofol
   - consider lasix with goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   - pressure support trial in am
   .
   #. Renal Failure: likely secondary to ATN and rhabdo. Currently
   improving with >50cc/hr of [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be post ATN diuresis. Temporary HD
   line in place, but looks erythematous.  The only reason to continue HD
   would be for volume O/L but given auto-diuresis, this is unlikely to be
   a problem.
   - f/u renal HD team consult
   - D/C HD line (does not look clean)
   - avoid nephrotoxins, closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   - f/u urine lytes
   # Diarrhea/H/o Crohns: Pt with recurrent diarrhea that has been C Diff
   negative.  Elev WBC ct could also be related to Crohns flair and
   unclear if pt has been on any mainetenance meds.  Pt had episodes of
   hematochezia at OSH and admission CT showed distal enteritis.
   - f/u repeat C Diff
   - OSH records for Crohn's
   - consider GI consult for colonoscopy in am vs. empiric treatment with
   steroids
   - consider repeat CT scan
   .
   # MS changes: Baseline MS is unclear but was improving at OSH.
   Unresponsiveness here likely due to boluses of sedation in transfer,
   waking up overnight.
   - will wean sedation & monitor
   - consider head CT if no improvement
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   -f/u OSH records
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now, CXR to confirmed OG tube placement.
   -restart TF
   - gentle 250cc boluses to maintain sbp
   - monitor lytes, replete aggressively
   .
   # Access: RIJ & subclavian temporary dialysis line
   - both should be removed today,  replace with 2 PIV
   .
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   .
   # Code: presume FULL
   .
   # Dispo: ICU
   .
   # Comm: with sister, [**Name (NI) 1387**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1388**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been intubated for airway control. She has several lines and catheters in place, including a multi-lumen line, dialysis catheter, and temporary dialysis line. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she has leukocytosis with an unclear etiology. She also has an elevated alkaline phosphatase level, which could be due to various causes such as congestive heart failure, volume overload, or liver dysfunction. The patient's urine culture shows a yeast infection, currently being treated with fluconazole. She has been receiving vancomycin for a possible line infection. The patient's recent blood cultures have been negative. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Line infection: The patient has multiple lines and catheters, increasing the risk of line-related infections. This is being treated with vancomycin.
2. Yeast infection: The patient's urine culture is positive for yeast, indicating a urinary tract yeast infection. This is being treated with fluconazole.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for airway control and has had

The patient has been intubated for airway control and has had prolonged intubation for unclear reasons. She has been diagnosed with leukocytosis, urinary tract infection (UTI), line infection, elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient's current condition is stable, but there are several potential medical complications that can arise.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, and there is a possibility of prolonged mechanical ventilation or extubation failure.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI), which can lead to further deterioration of renal function or the need for ongoing dialysis.
3. Infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and line infection, which may require appropriate antibiotic therapy and close monitoring for signs of sepsis.

   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Pt was intubated for airway control and has had
   prolonged intubation for unclear reasons.  Volume overload and MS
   likely contributing factors.  Per notes, attempted extubation on [**7-17**]
   but required re-intubation due to persistent hypoxia on BiPAP.  There
   is likely some component of chronic CO2 retention though no wheezing
   appreciated on exam.  Pt. tolerated PS most of yesterday, but is
   difficult to wean from propofol.
   - wean to PS, daily SBTs, RSBIs and wake ups
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   -change to fentanyl and midazolam, wean propofol
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   #Leukocytosis: Etiology unclear, WBC ct has ranged from 13-30 during
   recent admission, always afebrile, blood Cx neg to date. C Diff
   negative, RIJ line was + beta strep presumably treated with
   vancomycin.  Urine Cx + 100,000 yeast, treated with Fluconazole.  Both
   RIJ & R sub clavian appear erythematous.  CXR without focal infiltrate
   and steroids stopped on day 2 of admission. RUQ ultrasound shows
   persistent GB wall thickening but no other signs of cholecystitis,
   isolated elevation in Alk phos with normal Tbili, now trending down, is
   less suggestive suggestive of acalculous cholecystitis.  UA + WBCs,
   pending Cx.  D/C'd diflucan last night. Foley changed. WBC trending
   down.
   - f/u Blood/Urine Cx & sputum
   - f/u tip cultures
   - last day of Vancomycin- day [**8-31**] for ?line infection
   # Elevated Alk Phos: Pt was transferred due to concern of elev Alk Phos
   and GGT. Etiology still unclear, obstructive cholestasis seems unlikely
   given the repeatedly normal Tbili. Transaminases normal, hepatitis
   serologies negative. Repeated RUQ u/s show thickened GB wall with no
   stones and normal CBD, ascites but no pericholecystic fluid to suggest
   acute cholecystitis. It is unclear if this could be acalculous
   cholecystitis, would suspect that Tbili would also be elevated and pt
   would be less stable. CHF/volume overload can cause isolated Alk phos
   elevation. Fluconazole could also cause cholestatic picture.  Given h/o
   crohns, could have newly developped PSC though more commonly assoc with
   UC.   Alk Phos appears to be trending down from >900 at OSH to 617
   today
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - NPO
   -imaging unlikely to change management
   - if trend revereses, would consider liver consult in am & work up for
   PSC including smooth muscle Ab, p-ANCA
   #. Renal Failure: ATN [**12-23**] rhabdo. Currently improving with >100cc/hr of
   UOP, likely post ATN diuresis. HD line d/c'd yesterday (line from OSH)
   as no HD needed in immediate future
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins, closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # Diarrhea: Pt with recurrent loose stool that has been C Diff
   negative.  Most likely [**12-23**] crohn's disease.  Pt had episodes of
   hematochezia at OSH and admission CT showed distal enteritis.
   - OSH records for Crohn's
   - if continued diarrhea, could consider empiric treatment for Crohns.
   Particularly if chronic diarrhea causes metabolic alkalosis and a
   compensatory respiratory acidosis.
   # MS changes: Since hospitalization, her new baseline MS is unclear.
   Thought to be improving at OSH.  Unresponsiveness yesterday due to
   boluses of sedation in transfer, waking up overnight.  Agitation off
   propofol is impeding ability to look at baseline MS.
   [**Name14 (STitle) 1402**] wean sedation & monitor
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   -f/u OSH records
   # FEN: hypernatremia
   -started TF yesterday, bolus w/free water given hypernatremia
   - monitor lytes, replete aggressively
   # Access: new central line placed yesterday
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen

   .

   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Pt was intubated for airway control and has had
   prolonged intubation for unclear reasons.  Volume overload and MS
   likely contributing factors.  Per notes, attempted extubation on [**7-17**]
   but required re-intubation due to persistent hypoxia on BiPAP.  There
   is likely some component of chronic CO2 retention though no wheezing
   appreciated on exam.  Pt. tolerated PS most of yesterday, but is
   difficult to wean from propofol.
   - wean to PS, daily SBTs, RSBIs and wake ups
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - how to wean? wean propofol and add ativan or midaz?
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   #Leukocytosis: Etiology unclear, WBC ct has ranged from 13-30 during
   recent admission, always afebrile, blood Cx neg to date. C Diff
   negative, RIJ line was + beta strep presumably treated with
   vancomycin.  Urine Cx + 100,000 yeast, treated with Fluconazole.  Both
   RIJ & R sub clavian appear erythematous.  CXR without focal infiltrate
   and steroids stopped on day 2 of admission. RUQ ultrasound shows
   persistent GB wall thickening but no other signs of cholecystitis,
   isolated elevation in Alk phos with normal Tbili, now trending down, is
   less suggestive suggestive of acalculous cholecystitis.  UA + WBCs,
   pending Cx.  D/C'd diflucan last night. Foley changed. WBC trending
   down.
   - f/u Blood/Urine Cx & sputum
   - f/u tip cultures
   - last day of Vancomycin- day [**8-31**] for ?line infection
   # Elevated Alk Phos: Pt was transferred due to concern of elev Alk Phos
   and GGT. Etiology still unclear, obstructive cholestasis seems unlikely
   given the repeatedly normal Tbili. Transaminases normal, hepatitis
   serologies negative. Repeated RUQ u/s show thickened GB wall with no
   stones and normal CBD, ascites but no pericholecystic fluid to suggest
   acute cholecystitis. It is unclear if this could be acalculous
   cholecystitis, would suspect that Tbili would also be elevated and pt
   would be less stable. CHF/volume overload can cause isolated Alk phos
   elevation. Fluconazole could also cause cholestatic picture.  Given h/o
   crohns, could have newly developped PSC though more commonly assoc with
   UC.   Alk Phos appears to be trending down from >900 at OSH to ???
   today
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - NPO
   -imaging unlikely to change management
   - if not improving tomorrow would consider liver consult in am & work
   up for PSC including smooth muscle Ab, p-ANCA
   #. Renal Failure: ATN [**12-23**] rhabdo. Currently improving with >50cc/hr of
   [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be post ATN diuresis. HD line d/c'd yesterday (line from OSH)
   as no HD needed in immediate future
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins, closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # Diarrhea: Pt with recurrent loose stool that has been C Diff
   negative.  Most likely [**12-23**] crohn's disease.  Pt had episodes of
   hematochezia at OSH and admission CT showed distal enteritis.
   - f/u repeat C Diff
   - OSH records for Crohn's
   - if continued diarrhea, could consider empiric treatment for Crohns.
   # MS changes: Since hospitalization, her new baseline MS is unclear.
   Thought to be improving at OSH.  Unresponsiveness yesterday due to
   boluses of sedation in transfer, waking up overnight.  Agitation off
   propofol is impeding ability to look at baseline MS.
   [**Name14 (STitle) 1402**] wean sedation & monitor
   ???
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   -f/u OSH records
   # FEN: hypernatremia
   -started TF yesterday, bolus w/free water given hypernatremia
   - monitor lytes, replete aggressively
   # Access: new central line placed yesterday
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: ICU
   .
   # Comm: with sister, [**Name (NI) 1387**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1388**]

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital due to pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. She has been intubated for airway control and has had prolonged intubation for unclear reasons. The patient tolerated pressure support ventilation (PSV) yesterday but was unable to be weaned off propofol. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's prolonged intubation and difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation indicate a risk of respiratory failure.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has elevated white blood cell counts, which could be a sign of infection. However, the etiology of leukocytosis is unclear, as the patient has been afebrile and blood cultures have been negative to date.
3. Cholecystitis: The patient has persistent gallbladder wall thickening on ultrasound, but without other signs of cholecystitis. Isolated elevation in alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal total bilirubin (Tbili) suggests acalculous cholecystitis.
4. Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to rhabdomyolysis. Currently, her renal function is improving, but

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with diabetes mellitus who was found unresponsive and taken to the hospital. She was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis, rhabdomyolysis, acute renal failure, and attempted extubation but failed. Despite having a head CT scan that came back normal, the patient still exhibits poor neurologic function. The patient has a history of diabetes and Crohn's disease. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with low tidal volumes. Her vital signs are stable, but she remains poorly responsive. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelets, and lactate levels. The patient's mental status is being closely monitored, and she is receiving Haldol and weaning sedation as tolerated. Additional tests and treatments are being considered to determine the underlying cause of her altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Prolonged Intubation: The patient's failed extubation attempt indicates a potential complication of prolonged intubation, which can lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia, vocal cord damage, and increased risk of infection.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Given the patient's history of DKA and rhabdomyolysis, there is a possibility of developing ARDS, characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to impaired gas exchange.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Immobility due to being in

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with diabetes mellitus who was found unresponsive on the floor. She was taken to OSH and diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), rhabdomyolysis (rhabdo), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient attempted extubation but failed. A head CT scan showed no abnormalities. The patient has a history of diabetes, Crohn's disease, and an unknown allergy to penicillins and metoprolol. She received various medications including midazolam, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4 C, heart rate of 57 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 115/51 to 166/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. The patient is intubated and ventilated with a respiratory support mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow. The patient's neurological examination reveals poor responsiveness without further assessment. The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 17.2 K/uL, elevated blood glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's renal function is improving, and her urine output has increased. The patient is also experiencing diarrhea. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Patient was intubated most likely due to airway
   protection and new O2 requirements in the setting of agitation and
   non-possible non-invasive measures. Patient tried to be intubated in
   [**7-17**], but became hypoxic on BiPAP and agitated, so required
   re-inubation for airway protection. Patient still very agitated and
   with high-requirements of sedation medication. Non-responsive to verbal
   stimuli, only to pain. Patient also with chest tube and resolving
   pneumothorax and pleural fluid.
   - Stop Fentanyl/Midazolan
   - Start Propofol for sedation
   - Morphine PRN pain
   - Haldol PRN agitation
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   - Contult thoracics for chest tube pull out
   # Leukocytosis: Etiology unclear, WBC ct has ranged from 13-30 during
   recent admission, always afebrile, blood Cx neg to date. C Diff
   negative, RIJ line was + beta strep presumably treated with
   vancomycin.  Urine Cx + 100,000 yeast, treated with Fluconazole.  In
   the setting of [**Last Name (un) 1420**]
s without any current medications and agitated
   patient, it is unclear if this is the cause of the persistent
   leukocytosis.
   -          Consult GI for possible [**Last Name (un) 1420**]
s filaire
   -          Review data for past LP and analyze the possibility of one
   if patient not improving
   -          F/u WBC tomorrow
   -          F/u blood and urine cultures
   -          F/u tip culture
   -          Stop vancomycin today
   # Elevated Alk Phos: Pt was transferred for concerned of elevated Alk
   Phos and elevated GGT. Etiology unclear, but there is not a colestatic
   patern. CHF can also increase alk phos. Nicely trending down.
   -          Consult GI for possible PSC in setting of [**Last Name (un) 1420**]
   -          F/u l
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - NPO
   -imaging unlikely to change management
   - If patient not adequately responding, then may need CT of abdomen
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine improved today. Now with >100cc/hr of UOP,
   likely post ATN diuresis.
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # Diarrhea: Resolved.
   # MS changes: Same as yesterday.
   -will stop fentanyl and start propofol
   - Will give Haldol PRN
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient's head CT from yesterday showed no evidence of acute intracranial bleed. The patient has allergies to penicillins, metoprolol, and unknown allergens. The patient has been receiving various medications including propofol, fentanyl, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, morphine sulfate, and haloperidol.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 111/54 to 169/110 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's weight is currently 71.3 kg, with a height of 61 inches. The patient has received a total of 1,484 mL of fluids since midnight, with 907 mL given through intravenous fluids. The patient's urine output is 1,977 mL since midnight. 

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 12 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's respiratory system compliance and resistance index (RSBI) is 34, plateau pressure is 21 cmH2O, and peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) is 17 cmH2O. The patient's blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.34, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 49 mmHg, oxygen partial pressure (PaO2) of 173 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell (WBC) count ranging from 13.1 to 17.2 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hct) ranging from 28.4% to 32.0%, platelet (Plt) count ranging from 125 to 187 K/uL, blood glucose levels ranging from 53 to 170 mg/dL, and creatinine (Cr) levels ranging from 2.3 to 2.9 mg/dL. The patient's other lab values are within normal limits.

Assessment and plan:
The patient is currently in the ICU for altered mental status and is on mechanical ventilation. The patient has received various medications and interventions, including prophylactic heparin, pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and has a multi-lumen line inserted. The patient's vital signs and laboratory values are being closely monitored, and the healthcare team is managing the patient's glycemic control and fluid balance.

   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Patient was intubated most likely due to airway
   protection and new O2 requirements in the setting of agitation and
   non-possible non-invasive measures. Patient tried to be intubated in
   [**7-17**], but became hypoxic on BiPAP and agitated, so required
   re-inubation for airway protection. Patient still very agitated and
   with high-requirements of sedation medication. Non-responsive to verbal
   stimuli
   Pt was intubated for airway control and has had prolonged intubation
   for unclear reasons.  Volume overload and MS [**First Name (Titles) 1418**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1419**]
   factors.  Per notes, attempted extubation on [**7-17**] but required
   re-intubation due to persistent hypoxia on BiPAP.  There is likely some
   component of chronic CO2 retention though no wheezing appreciated on
   exam.  Pt. tolerated PS most of yesterday, but is difficult to wean
   from propofol.
   - wean to PS, daily SBTs, RSBIs and wake ups
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - change to fentanyl and midazolam, wean propofol
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   # Leukocytosis: Etiology unclear, WBC ct has ranged from 13-30 during
   recent admission, always afebrile, blood Cx neg to date. C Diff
   negative, RIJ line was + beta strep presumably treated with
   vancomycin.  Urine Cx + 100,000 yeast, treated with Fluconazole.  Both
   RIJ & R sub clavian appear erythematous.  CXR without focal infiltrate
   and steroids stopped on day 2 of admission. RUQ ultrasound shows
   persistent GB wall thickening but no other signs of cholecystitis,
   isolated elevation in Alk phos with normal Tbili, now trending down, is
   less suggestive suggestive of acalculous cholecystitis.  UA + WBCs,
   pending Cx.  D/C'd diflucan last night. Foley changed. WBC trending
   down.
   - f/u Blood/Urine Cx & sputum
   - f/u tip cultures
   - last day of Vancomycin- day [**8-31**] for ?line infection
   # Elevated Alk Phos: Pt was transferred due to concern of elev Alk Phos
   and GGT. Etiology still unclear, obstructive cholestasis seems unlikely
   given the repeatedly normal Tbili. Transaminases normal, hepatitis
   serologies negative. Repeated RUQ u/s show thickened GB wall with no
   stones and normal CBD, ascites but no pericholecystic fluid to suggest
   acute cholecystitis. It is unclear if this could be acalculous
   cholecystitis, would suspect that Tbili would also be elevated and pt
   would be less stable. CHF/volume overload can cause isolated Alk phos
   elevation. Fluconazole could also cause cholestatic picture.  Given h/o
   crohns, could have newly developped PSC though more commonly assoc with
   UC.   Alk Phos appears to be trending down from >900 at OSH to 617
   today
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - NPO
   -imaging unlikely to change management
   - if trend revereses, would consider liver consult in am & work up for
   PSC including smooth muscle Ab, p-ANCA
   #. Renal Failure: ATN [**12-23**] rhabdo. Currently improving with >100cc/hr of
   UOP, likely post ATN diuresis. HD line d/c'd yesterday (line from OSH)
   as no HD needed in immediate future
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins, closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # Diarrhea: Pt with recurrent loose stool that has been C Diff
   negative.  Most likely [**12-23**] crohn's disease.  Pt had episodes of
   hematochezia at OSH and admission CT showed distal enteritis.
   - OSH records for Crohn's
   - if continued diarrhea, could consider empiric treatment for Crohns.
   Particularly if chronic diarrhea causes metabolic alkalosis and a
   compensatory respiratory acidosis.
   # MS changes: Since hospitalization, her new baseline MS is unclear.
   Thought to be improving at OSH.  Unresponsiveness yesterday due to
   boluses of sedation in transfer, waking up overnight.  Agitation off
   propofol is impeding ability to look at baseline MS.
   [**Name14 (STitle) 1402**] wean sedation & monitor
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   -f/u OSH records
   # FEN: hypernatremia
   -started TF yesterday, bolus w/free water given hypernatremia
   - monitor lytes, replete aggressively
   # Access: new central line placed yesterday
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: ICU
   # Comm: with sister, [**Name (NI) 1387**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1388**]

She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a volume assist-control mode, set at a tidal volume of 500 mL and respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count ranging from 13-30 during the recent admission. The etiology of leukocytosis is unclear, but it could be related to a central line infection, as the patient had beta-streptococcal bacteremia from a right internal jugular line. The patient also has yeast in her urine, which has been treated with fluconazole. Both the right internal jugular and subclavian lines appear erythematous, but there are no focal infiltrates on chest X-ray.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with respiratory failure and a high risk of aspiration. The patient has been experiencing nausea after restarting tube feeds, so the feeds were stopped. The patient received free water boluses and had a CT scan of the abdomen, which showed mild thickening of the distal terminal ileal wall and cecum compatible with Crohn's disease. There is no evidence of active inflammation. The patient also has bilateral large consolidations with associated pleural effusions, left greater than right, which are suspicious for pneumonia. Mild mediastinal lymphadenopathy may be reactive. The right chest tube is positioned within the minor fissure. There is evidence of anasarca and pulmonary edema. The endotracheal tube terminates approximately 2 cm above the carina, and repositioning by moving the tube approximately 2 cm superiorly is suggested. The patient has mildly distended gallbladder without evidence of gallstones and mild intra-abdominal and pelvic ascites. No large intra-abdominal fluid collection is noted.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure puts him at risk for further deterioration in lung function and potential complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Aspiration: Due to the patient's high risk of aspiration, there is a potential for aspiration pneumonia or chemical pneumonitis if aspirated material enters the lower airways.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was transferred from another hospital after a 10-day admission for pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.

Current assessment:
- The patient is still experiencing respiratory failure and is intubated for airway protection.
- She is agitated and requires high sedation medication.
- She is responsive only to pain and not verbal stimuli.
- She has a chest tube and is resolving pneumothorax and pleural fluid.
- Her leukocyte count is elevated, but the cause is unclear.
- Her alkaline phosphatase level is elevated, but the cause is also unclear.
- She has improved renal function, likely post-acute tubular necrosis diuresis.
- She previously had diarrhea, which has resolved.
- She has changes in mental status and is on various medications.
- She has a history of diabetes, which is currently being managed with insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Pneumonia: The presence of bilateral large consolidations with associated pleural effusions suggests a possible pneumonia. This can be a complication due to the patient's compromised respiratory status and prolonged immobility.
2. Aspiration: The patient's high risk of aspiration due to impaired airway protection increases the likelihood of aspiration pneumonia.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient is currently in the ICU and is intubated due to airway protection and new oxygen requirements.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. Close monitoring and appropriate ventilator management are necessary.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: Due to the risk of aspiration, the patient may be susceptible to developing aspiration pneumonia. Adequate positioning and careful feeding practices should be implemented to minimize this risk.
3. Pneumonia: The CT scan shows bilateral large consolidations with associated pleural effusions, which are suspicious for pneumonia. Antibiotic therapy should be initiated based on culture and sensitivity results.
4. Pleural Effusion: The patient has pleural effusions, and the fluid is transudate by Light's criteria. Further evaluation and management may be required, including drainage if necessary.
5. Crohn's Disease Flare: Although the CT scan does not show active inflammation, there is mild thickening of the distal terminal ileal wall and cecum compatible with Crohn's disease. Monitoring for signs of a Crohn's flare-up is essential

   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Patient was intubated most likely due to airway
   protection and new O2 requirements in the setting of agitation and
   non-possible non-invasive measures. Patient tried to be intubated in
   [**7-17**], but became hypoxic on BiPAP and agitated, so required
   re-inubation for airway protection. Pt still very sedated to extubate
   since she received extra propofol boluses for MRI. Chest tube was to
   water seal yesterday. No drainage and no change in CXR. Pleural fluid
   is transudate by Light
s criteria.
   - Decrease Propofol today and give her another trial.
   - Morphine PRN pain
   - Haldol PRN agitation
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   - Pull chest tube today.
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Following Alk phos, which is nicely trending down.
   - F/u GI recs
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine improved today. Now with >100cc/hr of UOP,
   likely post ATN diuresis.
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # MS changes: Same as yesterday.
   -will stop fentanyl and start propofol
   - Will give Haldol PRN
   - F/u EEG interpretation
   - LP today
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN
   -Increase free water boluses per Tube Feed @ 400
   -D51/2NS PRN
   # Access: new central line placed on [**7-22**]
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: ICU
   # Comm: with sister, [**Name (NI) 1387**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1388**]

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient was intubated due to airway protection and new oxygen requirements during agitation. She received extra propofol boluses for an MRI and is still very sedated to extubate. A chest tube was placed, but no drainage was observed, and there were no changes in the chest X-ray. Pleural fluid is transudate by Light's criteria. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 71 bpm, blood pressure of 138/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 95%, and sinus rhythm. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently intubated due to respiratory failure, and sedation is still a concern. There is a plan to decrease propofol and give another trial for extubation.
2. Elevated Alk Phos: The patient has an elevated alkaline phosphatase level, which may be due to ischemic biliary ducts after being down. The trend of Alk phos is nicely trending down.
3. Renal Failure:

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the ICU due to pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient had an unsuccessful attempt at intubation on July 17th and required re-intubation for airway protection. Currently, she is sedated and unable to be extubated. The chest tube was removed yesterday as there was no drainage and no change in chest X-ray. Pleural fluid is transudate by Light's criteria. The patient's white blood cell count has improved from 13 to 9.3. Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are likely due to ischemia after shock, and it is recommended to follow them. The patient's creatinine level has improved, indicating possible post-acute tubular necrosis diuresis. The patient's diabetes is being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin. She also has hypernatremia in the setting of post-acute tubular necrosis. The patient has a new central line placed on July 22nd, and her nutritional status is being repleted with fiber at a rate of 50 mL/hour. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and sedated, which increases the risk of ventil

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaint is respiratory failure following diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), pancreatitis, and shock. The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins and metoprolol, and has been receiving various medications including propofol, pantoprazole, hydromorphone, heparin sodium, morphine sulfate, and haloperidol.

The patient's vital signs are relatively stable with a temperature of 37.7 degrees Celsius, heart rate ranging from 51-108 beats per minute, blood pressure between 106/50-138/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's fluid balance shows a total intake of 4,125 mL and output of 3,838 mL, with urine output of 3,688 mL. The respiratory support includes being on a ventilator with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) set at 50%.

Laboratory results indicate elevated levels of white blood cells (WBC), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, glucose, and lactic acid. The patient also has a slightly low hemoglobin (Hct) level and elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST). Other lab values are within normal ranges.

   Assessment and Plan
   60 y/o F with PMHx of DMII & Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 day adm after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA, resp failure,
   rhadomyolysis and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Patient was intubated most likely due to airway
   protection and new O2 requirements in the setting of agitation and
   non-possible non-invasive measures. Patient tried to be intubated in
   [**7-17**], but became hypoxic on BiPAP and agitated, so required
   re-inubation for airway protection. Pt still very sedated to extubate
   since she received extra propofol boluses for MRI. Chest tube was to
   water seal yesterday. No drainage and no change in CXR. Pleural fluid
   is transudate by Light
s criteria.
   - Decrease Propofol today
   - Morphine PRN pain
   - Haldol PRN agitation
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   - monitor chest tube output, leave to suction
   - Pull chest tube today.
   # Leukocytosis: Improved, now WBC 9.3 from 13.
   # Elevated Alk Phos: GI consulted yesterday and they suggest that
   etiology of elevated enzymes is ischemia after shock. They recommend
   following them. CT of abdomen showed disteded gallblader without stones
   or thickening; mild inflammation of terminal illeus, presence of
   ascities.
   - F/u GI recs
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   - If patient not adequately responding, then may need CT of abdomen
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine improved today. Now with >100cc/hr of UOP,
   likely post ATN diuresis.
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # MS changes: Same as yesterday.
   -will stop fentanyl and start propofol
   - Will give Haldol PRN
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN
   -Increase free water boluses per Tube Feed
   -D51/2NS PRN
   # Access: new central line placed on [**7-22**]
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: ICU
   # Comm: with sister, [**Name (NI) 1387**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 1388**]

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated due to airway protection and new oxygen requirements in the setting of agitation and non-invasive measures.
- Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has improved from 13 to 9.3.
- Elevated Alk Phos: The patient has elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, which are being monitored. A CT scan of the abdomen showed distended gallbladder without stones or thickening, mild inflammation of the terminal ileum, and presence of ascites.
- Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have improved, indicating possible post-acute tubular necrosis diuresis.
- MS changes: The patient is experiencing mental status changes, including agitation and non-responsiveness.
- Diabetes: The patient presented with pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with intravenous fluids and insulin. Now being managed with sliding scale and fixed-dose insulin.
- Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia in the setting of post-acute tubular necrosis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-inch tall, 71.3 kg male who was admitted with respiratory failure and altered mental status. The patient is currently intubated and sedated. Chest tube removal was performed overnight. An MRI of the brain was normal. The patient continues to be agitated despite receiving haloperidol.

Vital signs show a temperature of 37.9°C (100.3°F), heart rate of 73 bpm (with a range of 55-108 bpm), blood pressure ranging from 118/56 mmHg to 173/99 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute (with a range of 12-44 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient has received various medications including hydromorphone, morphine sulfate, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and haloperidol. The patient's review of systems remains unchanged except for agitation.

The patient's flowsheet data indicates fluid balance, hemodynamic monitoring, respiratory support, and lab results. The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 18 cmH2O. The patient's ABG results show pH 7.48, PaCO2 35 mmHg, PaO2 224, and HCO3- 27 mEq/L. The patient's blood glucose level is elevated at 191 mg/dL.

Physical examination findings include the patient being intubated and sedated, with chest tube removal, normal heart sounds, soft and non-tender abdomen, and warm and dry extremities. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased platelet count, elevated creatinine, and elevated blood urea nitrogen levels. Other lab values are within normal range.

Assessment and Plan:
1) Respiratory Failure: The patient continues to be limited by mental status.
Plan: Continue assisted control ventilation and plan for tracheostomy.
2) Low-grade temperature: Check cultures/sputum. If positive, consider bronchoscopy, line change, and empiric antibiotics.
3) Elevated Alk phos: Trending down.
4) Altered Mental Status: LP/EEG results.
5) DM:
6) Acute renal failure/ATN: Resolving.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to limited mental status.
2. Infection: The patient's low-grade temperature and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an underlying infection. If confirmed, it could lead to worsening respiratory status and sepsis.
3. Bleeding: The patient's elevated platelet count and prolonged PTT may increase the risk of bleeding.
4. Renal Dysfunction: The patient's elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure. If not managed appropriately, this could lead to further renal dysfunction.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, potentially leading to complications such as pressure ulcers, aspiration pneumonia, or falls.

The patient's condition has been unstable with fluctuations in vital signs and lab results. The patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. The patient's tracheostomy was performed at 7:30 am, and there were episodes of agitation and unresponsiveness to commands after decreasing propofol infusion. The patient did not respond to morphine and haloperidol, so the propofol infusion was increased.

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been intubated for an extended period, increasing the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory symptoms and culture surveillance is necessary.

3. Stress ulcers: The patient's critical illness and prolonged ICU stay increase the risk of stress ulcers. Proton pump inhibitors have been initiated for gastric protection.

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure (ARF) requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient underwent several procedures including the placement of a tracheostomy, central line, and PICC line. She is currently on mechanical ventilation support and is being managed with propofol for sedation, pain medications, and anxiolytics. The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and alkaline phosphatase levels, improved renal function, and electrolyte imbalances.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still on assisted ventilation support, and there is a risk of further respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or tracheostomy-related infections.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia in the setting of post-acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which requires careful management of fluid balance and electrolytes.
3. Elevated Alk Phos: The patient's elevated alkaline phosphatase level may indicate ischemic biliary ducts or other liver-related issues. Monitoring liver function tests and following gastrointestinal recommendations would be important.
4. Renal Failure: Although the patient's creatinine level has improved, there is still

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found unresponsive with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. She has been in the ICU since then and is currently intubated on assisted control ventilation mode.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could be a complication of her underlying conditions such as pancreatitis or due to the recent tracheostomy placement. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
2. Hyperkalemia: The patient has a history of rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to elevated potassium levels. This can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has a history of acute renal failure and is currently showing signs of post-acute tubular necrosis (ATN) diuresis. This may indicate ongoing kidney injury, which requires close monitoring and management.
4. Ischemic Biliary Ducts: The elevated alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos) levels suggest potential ischemic biliary ducts. This could be a complication of the patient's recent illness or previous surgeries.
5. Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infection (CLAB

Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a chief complaint of acute respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. They have undergone a tracheostomy and peg tube placement. The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins and metoprolol, and unknown allergies. They received vancomycin on 07/27/2114 at 10:00 AM.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 60 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 114/49 mmHg to 196/98 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on FiO2 of 50%. The patient's weight is 69.2 kg, down from 75 kg at admission.

The patient's fluid balance shows an input of 3,272 mL and output of 4,250 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 978 mL. Respiratory support includes being on a ventilator in CMV mode with Vt set at 500 mL, RR set at 12, PEEP at 5 cmH2O, FiO2 at 50%, PIP at 30 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 19 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.3 g/dL, platelet count of 248 K/uL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, blood glucose ranging from 135 mg/dL to 191 mg/dL, and electrolyte imbalances including sodium at 27 mEq/L, potassium at 3.5 mEq/L, chloride at 115 mEq/L, bicarbonate at 28.9%, and magnesium at 1.7 mg/dL.

The patient's assessment and plan include several conditions. Firstly, acute respiratory failure is likely secondary to impaired neuro status with underlying lung congestion. A tracheostomy has been performed, and the plan is to change to pressure support ventilation and evaluate the patient's ability to wean off the ventilator. Secondly, mental status change is planned to be managed by weaning off propofol and haloperidol. Thirdly, increased alkaline phosphatase is improving. Fourthly, acute renal failure or acute tubular necrosis is also improving, and the plan is to continue monitoring BUN, creatinine, and urine output. Lastly, diabetes mellitus, feeding, access, upper extremity swelling, and other issues are also addressed in the plan.

Potential medical complications that can arise include further deterioration of respiratory status, development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and continued renal dysfunction.

   60yo F with PMHx of DMII and Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,

   # Resp Failure: Patient had successful trach placed today and continues

   anxiolytics. Will continue haldol for now since it may be helping.

   - Haldol PRN agitation

   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine improved today. Now with >100cc/hr of UOP,

   # MS changes: LP negative, EEG shows encephalopathic picture

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease who was admitted to the ICU after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure (ARF) requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient underwent percutaneous tracheostomy placement and continues to receive assisted ventilation (AC) with plans to wean off to pressure support (PS). She is still on propofol due to agitation and will be gradually decreased. Haloperidol is being used for agitation as well. Nebulizations of albuterol and atrovent are given every six hours. The goal is to achieve a negative fluid balance of 1-2 liters per day. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated, which is likely due to ischemic biliary ducts. Renal function has improved with an increased urine output of over 100 cc/hr, indicating post-acute tubular necrosis (ATN) diuresis. The patient has a history of diet-controlled diabetes but presented with pancreatitis and DKA. Insulin therapy is being managed with a sliding scale and fixed dose. Hypernatremia is present in the setting of post-ATN. The patient has a new central line placed on [**7-22**], and a PICC line was placed today. There is concern about possible

   60yo F with PMHx of DMII and Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,
   respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis and ARF requiring intermittent
   dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Trach placed yesterday, on CPAP/PSV at 15/5 which will
   be weaned off to PS as tolerated. Will continue to attempt to wean off,
   although some tachypnea and hypoxia on several checks overnight. This
   is likely due to some problems with her trach placement, including
   bleeding/secretions into lung. Also, would continue to ensure negative
   fluid balance to prevent fluid retention in the lungs.
   - wean as tolerated to [**3-26**] on vent, reassess
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs q6hr
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day
   -f/u CXR
   #Fever: likely secondary to pulmonary insult during tracheostomy
   placement. Will follow up with CXR and monitor fever curve. No need to
   restart antibiotics at this point until there is reason to believe she
   is re-infected.
   -CXR
   -monitor fever curve
   -follow WBC
   -f/u cultures
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Following Alk phos, which is trending down. Also history of
   Crohns disease. However currently patient is denying abdominal pain and
   not having increased or bloody BMs.
   - F/u GI recs if any
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine continues to trend down, and UOP has been
   maintained.
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # MS changes: Sedation has been decreased and zydis added with good
   resolution of MS changes. She is able to communicate, both attempting
   to vocalize and writing on paper. Today patient was sitting in chair
   with family at bedside which is a significant improvement.
   - continue zydis as needed
   - Haldol PRN for agitation
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN improving with free
   water
   -1200cc free water per tube feed
   -replete electrolytes as needed
   -nutrition consult
   -follow Na

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient underwent percutaneous tracheostomy, ultrasound of the upper arm to rule out deep vein thrombosis (negative), removal of a central line, placement of a PICC line, and pancultured for fever. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 101.5°F, heart rate 95 bpm, blood pressure 162/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 95%. The patient's physical examination reveals jaundice in the sclera, regular heart sounds, clear lungs with crackles at the bases while supine, soft and non-tender abdomen, warm and well-perfused extremities, and no rashes. The patient is alert and oriented to place, interactive, and able to respond to questions but is unable to vocalize and attempts to write but is too weak. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, creatinine, glucose, and liver enzymes. The patient's respiratory status is being managed with CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator, and the plan is to wean off the ventilator

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the hospital after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure (ARF) requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient underwent percutaneous tracheostomy and is currently on CPAP/PSV mode of ventilation. She is also receiving propofol for agitation and haloperidol for sedation. Her current vital signs include a temperature of 101.5°F, blood pressure of 162/70 mmHg, heart rate of 95 bpm, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient has shown improvement in her renal function, with an increased urine output of >100cc/hr. Her laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient's pain and anxiety are being managed with pain medications and haloperidol as needed. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Since the patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, she is at risk of developing VAP. Regular assessment of respiratory status and appropriate antibiotic therapy should be considered if necessary.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's recent immobilization and the presence of central lines

   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,
   respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis and ARF requiring intermittent
   dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Trach, on CPAP/PSV at 8/5 which will be weaned off to
   PS as tolerated. This is likely due to some problems with her trach
   placement, including bleeding/secretions into lung. Also, would
   continue to ensure negative fluid balance to prevent fluid retention in
   the lungs. CXR this morning with improved lung volumes and previously
   noted opacities which appear to be improving.
   - wean as tolerated to [**3-26**] on vent, reassess
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs prn
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day, if slows down ok to give lasix
   -f/u CXR
   #Fever: Initially thought to be secondary to pulmonary insult during
   tracheostomy placement. However blood cultures taken from her picc line
   grew out GPC in clusters/pairs yesterday. Will follow up with CXR and
   monitor fever curve. No need to restart antibiotics at this point until
   there is reason to believe she is re-infected.
   -CXR
   -monitor fever curve
   -follow WBC
   -f/u cultures
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Following Alk phos, which is trending down. Also history of
   Crohns disease. However currently patient is denying abdominal pain and
   not having increased or bloody BMs.
   - F/u GI recs if any
   - trend LFTs, Alk Phos, GGT
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine continues to trend down, and UOP has been
   maintained.
   - f/u renal recs
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # MS changes: Sedation has been decreased and zydis added with good
   resolution of MS changes. She is able to communicate, both attempting
   to vocalize and writing on paper. Today patient was sitting in chair
   with family at bedside which is a significant improvement.
   - continue zydis as needed
   - Haldol PRN for agitation
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN improving with free
   water
   -1200cc free water per tube feed
   -replete electrolytes as needed
   -nutrition consult
   -follow Na

   60yo F with PMHx of DMII and Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,
   respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis and ARF requiring intermittent
   dialysis.
   # Resp Failure: Trach, on CPAP/PSV at 8/5 which will be weaned off to
   PS as tolerated. This is likely due to some problems with her trach
   placement, including bleeding/secretions into lung. Also, would
   continue to ensure negative fluid balance to prevent fluid retention in
   the lungs. CXR this morning with improved lung volumes and previously
   noted opacities which appear to be improving.
   - wean as tolerated to [**3-26**] on vent, reassess
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs prn only
   - goal net negative 1-2L/day, if slows down ok to give lasix
   -trach collar
   -speech, swallow eval
   #Fever: Initially thought to be secondary to pulmonary insult during
   tracheostomy placement. However blood cultures taken from her picc line
   grew out GPC in clusters/pairs yesterday. Will repeat cultures today
   from PICC and peripheral to evaluate need for restarting vancomycin.
   Also continue to monitor fever trend and WBC. Given improvement in
   respiratory status unlikely this is due to pulmonary etiology.
   -monitor fever curve
   -follow WBC
   -culture PICC and peripheral
   -vanco IV if spikes
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Following Alk phos, which is trending down. Also history of
   Crohns disease. However currently patient is denying abdominal pain and
   not having increased or bloody BMs.

   possible causes and treatments
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine continues to trend down, and good UOP has
   been maintained. Continue IV fluids as needed but ideally would like to

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the ICU after being found down with pancreatitis, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure (ARF) requiring intermittent dialysis.

The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV mode at 8/5 cmH2O due to respiratory failure, which is likely due to issues with her tracheostomy placement, including bleeding and secretions into the lung. The goal is to wean her off the ventilator as tolerated. She is also receiving Albuterol/Atrovent nebs as needed.

The patient has been experiencing fever, initially thought to be secondary to the pulmonary insult during tracheostomy placement. However, blood cultures from her PICC line grew out Gram-positive cocci in clusters/pairs yesterday. Repeat cultures will be taken today from the PICC and peripheral lines to evaluate the need for restarting vancomycin. The patient's fever trend and white blood cell count will also be monitored.

The patient has elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after being down. Her alkaline phosphatase levels are trending down, and she has a history of Crohn's disease. However, she denies abdominal pain and does not have increased or bloody bowel movements.

   Assessment and Plan
   60yo F with PMHx of DMII and Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,
   respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis and ARF requiring intermittent
   dialysis.
    # Resp Failure: Trach, currently on 15/5 FiO2 of 40% (down from 50%).
   This is likely due to some problems with her trach placement, including
   bleeding/secretions into lung.
   - cxr , in comparison with study of [**7-29**], the right subclavian line has
   been removed. Enlargement of cardiac silhouette with pulmonary vascular
   congestion and bilateral pleural effusions persists.
   - wean as tolerated to [**8-26**] today on vent with ultimate goal to trach
   mask
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs prn
   - goal net negative 1 liter /day. however nursing concern over giving
   lasix so was held, only out -300 cc yesterday, especially with concern
   for pulmonary vascular congestion, would like to diuresis if possible
   -trach collar in place
   -speech, swallow eval consult ordered, state that too early for patient
   to be evaluated at this point
   - patient started on levoquin yesterday for increased secretions
   (aspiration pneumonia coverage)
   - will re-check sputum today
    #Fever: Initially thought to be secondary to pulmonary insult during
   tracheostomy placement. However blood cultures taken from her picc line
   grew out GPC in clusters/pairs yesterday. Will repeat cultures today
   from PICC and peripheral to evaluate need for restarting vancomycin.
   Also continue to monitor fever trend and WBC. Given improvement in
   respiratory status unlikely this is due to pulmonary etiology.
   - repeat PICC culture tip wound culture pending
   - c. diff negative
   - urine culture from [**7-27**] + yeast,  UA from [**7-27**] with moderate blood,
   trace LE
   - will re-send another UA and Ucx today and follow up
   - blood culture from [**7-29**] still no growth to date
   -monitor fever curve, WBC
   - started on IV vancomycin yesterday in the setting of one positive
   blood culture, will continue for now
   - consider surveillance cultures tomorrow AM
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Alk phos elevated has continued to trend down since
   admission. Also history of Crohns disease s/p surgeries in the remote
   past. However currently patient is denying abdominal pain and not
   having increased or bloody BMs.
   - trend alk phos- if begins to plateau will re-consult GI for other
   possible causes and treatments
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine elevated on admission, continues to trend
   down, now 1.2, and good UOP has been maintained. Ideally would like to
   keep negative and encourage diuresis.
   - if net + > 500 cc, will give lasix, otherwise will leave alone
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
    # MS changes: Sedation has been decreased and zydis added with good
   resolution of MS changes. Pt able to communicate, both attempting to
   vocalize and writing on paper. yesterday patient was sitting in chair
   with family at bedside which is a significant improvement. Is slowly
   getting stronger and trying to vocalize questions.
   - continue zydis as needed
   - PT/OT evaluation, speech-n-swallow eval deferred as above for now
    # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN improving with free
   water
   -continue free water boluses, in order to try to normalize sodium
   levels, consider increase in frequency or dose as needed
   -replete electrolytes as needed
   -follow Na
   # Access: PICC* culture, so PICC d/c yesterday, now with peripheral IV
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: would begin screening for rehab today if cultures continue to
   be negative and can wean to trach mask only
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of borderline diabetes and Crohn's disease. She was admitted to the ICU after being found down with DKA, pancreatitis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis. The patient has been on various medications including insulin, morphine sulfate, and heparin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's tracheostomy placement has been associated with bleeding and secretions into the lungs, leading to persistent respiratory failure. The goal is to wean her off the ventilator and eventually tracheostomy collar.
2. Fever: The patient initially had a fever thought to be secondary to pulmonary insult during tracheostomy placement. However, blood cultures from the PICC line grew out GPC in clusters/pairs, indicating a possible infection. Further cultures will be repeated to evaluate the need for restarting vancomycin.
3. Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase: The patient's elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after being down. The levels have trended down since admission. Other possible causes such as Crohn's disease will be considered if the trend plateaus.
4. Renal Failure: The patient had elevated creatinine levels on admission, which have now trended down. Good urine output has been maintained. It is important to keep the patient's fluid balance negative

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a medical history of borderline diabetes and Crohn's disease. She was transferred from another hospital after a 10-day admission due to being found down with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), pancreatitis, respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis, and acute renal failure requiring intermittent dialysis.

The patient has been experiencing episodes of atrial flutter, which appears to be secondary to mucus plugging. She has been given a diltiazem drip, and her heart rate has stabilized in normal sinus rhythm.

The patient's blood pressure has remained stable without any chest pain or drop in blood pressure. However, she continues to have thick yellow secretions. She has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on CPAP/PSV mode with a set tidal volume of 400 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 21 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The respiratory system inspection reveals mild rhonchi bilaterally.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 105 bpm with a range of 52-171 bpm, blood pressure of 151/130 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with a range of 15-32 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. Her weight is currently 66.7 kg, and

   Assessment and Plan
   60yo F with PMHx of DMII and Crohns who was transferred from OSH after
   10 days admission after being found down with pancreatitis, DKA,
   respiratory failure, rhabdomyolysis and ARF requiring intermittent
   dialysis.
    # Resp Failure: Trach, currently on 15/5 FiO2 of 40% (down from 50%).
   This is likely due to some problems with her trach placement, including
   bleeding/secretions into lung. CXR yesterday morning with improved lung
   volumes and previously noted opacities which appear to be improving.
   - wean as tolerated to [**3-26**] on vent with ultimate goal to trach mask
   - Albuterol/atrovent nebs prn
   - goal net negative 1 liter /day. however nursing concern over giving
   lasix so was held, only out -300 cc yesterday
   -trach collar in place
   -speech, swallow eval consult ordered, will follow-up with results
   #Fever: Initially thought to be secondary to pulmonary insult during
   tracheostomy placement. However blood cultures taken from her picc line
   grew out GPC in clusters/pairs yesterday. Will repeat cultures today
   from PICC and peripheral to evaluate need for restarting vancomycin.
   Also continue to monitor fever trend and WBC. Given improvement in
   respiratory status unlikely this is due to pulmonary etiology.
   - repeat PICC culture tip wound culture pending
   - c. diff negative
   - urine culture from [**7-27**] + yeast,  UA from [**7-27**] with moderate blood,
   trace LE
   - will re-send another UA and Ucx today and follow up
   - blood culture from [**7-29**] still no growth to date
   -monitor fever curve, WBC
   -vanco IV if spikes
   # Elevated Alk Phos:  Most likely due to ischemic biliary ducts after
   being down. Following Alk phos, which is trending down. Also history of
   Crohns disease. However currently patient is denying abdominal pain and
   not having increased or bloody BMs.
   - F/u GI recs if any
   - trend alk phos- if begins to plateau will re-consult GI for other
   possible causes and treatments
   #. Renal Failure: Creatinine continues to trend down, and good UOP has
   been maintained. Continue IV fluids as needed but ideally would like to
   keep negative and encourage diuresis.
   - if autodiuresis slows, consider lasix as bp tolerates
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - closely monitor I&O and trend BUN/Cr.
   # MS changes: Sedation has been decreased and zydis added with good
   resolution of MS changes. Pt able to communicate, both attempting to
   vocalize and writing on paper. yesterday patient was sitting in chair
   with family at bedside which is a significant improvement. Is slowly
   getting stronger and trying to vocalize questions.
   - continue zydis as needed
   - PT/OT evaluation, speech-n-swallow eval
   # Diabetes: Pt with h/o diet controlled DM who presented with
   pancreatitis and DKA, initially managed with IVF & insulin gtt. Now
   being managed with sliding scale and fixed dose insulin.
   - continue regular insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: hypernatremia in the setting of Post-ATN improving with free
   water
   -will increase free water boluses, in order to try to normalize sodium
   levels
   -replete electrolytes as needed
   -follow Na
   # Access: PICC* culture, so PICC d/c yesterday, now with peripheral IV
   # PPx: Heparin sc TID, PPI, bowel regimen
   # Code:  FULL
   # Dispo: would begin screening for rehab today if cultures continue to
   be negative and can wean to trach mask only
